comments.body:
Hi @sofiafaro-da 

We (@moritzkiefer-da @robin-da) had a long discussion and have decided that because different terminals pick up the path settings differently telling the users to restart their computers is the easiest and safest thing to do.

To expand on that: While you can certainly find ways around restarting, the kind of person that can do that reliably and knows what went wrong if they mess it up is the kind of person that won’t read those instructions anyway. For people less experienced with this, restarting might be annoying but at least it’s reliable and easy.

I definitely disagree with this. Requiring the user to restart is a massive pain. (Recall that we have a goal of improving the user experience of the getting started guide...)

On Mac the instructions I gave are definitely sufficient (just restart the Terminal app). On Linux, I'm not sure, but I'd be much happier if we could avoid asking our users to restart their machines like we're installing a Windows XP app.

> Recall that we have a goal of improving the user experience of the getting started guide...

I know but we changed this _because_ we’ve had a bunch of users that got confused by their shell environment and had issues with this. In the end, they solved it with a restart anyway.

I’m fine with changing it on MacOS if it works (but we should at least check that iterm2 does the same as terminal app) but I don’t think changing it on Linux is an improvement.

It's a one-off thing that makes sure that PATH is set. It's not something that a user needs to do over and over so the "pain" of restarting is really minimal (if any). We had really a bunch of issues with making it work in different terminals. 

Now if we can _guarantee_ that this works 100% on MacOS it would be a great improvement
